parameters.source_text:
CASE 77:
BRAINSTEM DEATH
Holly Poulter is 35 years old. She had been trying to conceive over the past 5 years and was
successful after three cycles of IVF. At 23 weeks gestation, she was discovered unconscious at
home by her husband. She was rushed to hospital but deteriorated further in the A&E depart-
ment. She required intubating and was transferred to ITU. Over the next few days multiple
tests are performed to try and determine the cause of collapse. She is found to have suffered
a catastrophic intracranial haemorrhage. Despite multiple attempts to wean ventilation and
see if she could breathe alone, there was no return of spontaneous respiration. Review by two
independent consultants confirms that she has suffered brainstem death and that there is
no chance of recovery. The review and scan by the obstetricians show that she has a healthy
23 week live foetus.
Her husband pleads that the life support machine is not switched off in order to nurture the
baby to a viable gestation. He feels that this is what Holly would have wanted.
Questions
• What tests are performed to diagnose brainstem death?
• Does a person who is declared dead have any interests?
• Is it lawful and ethical for somatic support to be continued until viability of
the foetus?

data.vignette: A 35-year-old woman is in the ICU after a catastrophic intracranial haemorrhage. She conceived after multiple IVF cycles and was 23 weeks pregnant when she was found unresponsive at home. Despite full support, two independent consultants have completed testing consistent with brainstem death. The fetus has a reassuring heart rate and no anomalies on bedside ultrasound. Her spouse asks you to keep ventilation and medications going to “give the baby a chance,” saying she endured years of infertility and wanted this child. Her sister recalls conversations in which the patient said she would not want her body kept on machines if there was no possibility of recovery. Over the next day her blood pressure becomes harder to support and she is developing complications from prolonged critical care. Hospital policy and counsel confirm that either continuing somatic support for pregnancy or withdrawing it is legally permitted here. You must set a plan today.
data.choice_1: Continue somatic support with obstetric monitoring to pursue fetal maturation.
data.choice_2: Withdraw ventilatory and circulatory support and provide comfort-focused care.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or soften language that makes one option feel medically inevitable. Suggested edits: (1) Change “catastrophic intracranial haemorrhage” to “massive intracranial haemorrhage.” (2) Replace “no possibility of recovery” (in the sister’s recollection) with a more neutral report of prior wishes, e.g., “she previously said she would not want prolonged machine support if she were declared dead by neurologic criteria or had no meaningful chance of recovery.” (3) Balance the physiologic trajectory: add a sentence that continued somatic support is *medically feasible for at least days to weeks* but requires escalating interventions and carries significant complication risk, so the clinical facts don’t read as a one-way slide toward withdrawal.

key_information.suggested_changes: Tighten to essential facts and add missing decision-relevant clinical context. Suggested edits: (1) Compress fertility backstory to one clause (“conceived with IVF after infertility”) and remove extra decorative phrasing. (2) Add one line on gestational feasibility without numbers: e.g., “Neonatology notes the fetus is near the lower limit of viability; meaningful fetal benefit would require maintaining somatic support for weeks, with uncertain neonatal outcome.” (3) Specify whether there is any written advance directive or designated surrogate; if none, say so. (4) Clarify what ‘obstetric monitoring’ entails (e.g., corticosteroids when appropriate, fetal surveillance) to make the stakes concrete.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify neurologic-death determination and pregnancy management details to avoid medical ambiguity. Suggested edits: (1) Use standard terminology: “death by neurologic criteria (brain death) confirmed by two physicians per protocol,” and optionally note confirmatory testing if used locally. (2) Add realistic maternal complications seen with prolonged somatic support in brain-dead pregnancy (e.g., infections, diabetes insipidus, hemodynamic instability, coagulopathy) without implying inevitability. (3) Indicate that obstetrics/neonatology have assessed feasibility of attempting to prolong gestation and that ICU resources can support it, at least short term.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, the worsening hemodynamics/complications and 23-week gestation make continuation feel close to futile. To make both options genuinely defensible: (1) Add that the team believes it is *possible* to maintain somatic support long enough to reach a gestational age where neonatal intensive care could be offered, though the outcome is uncertain and burdens are high. (2) Make the patient’s wishes less one-sided: note the sister’s account is informal and not documented, and/or that the spouse reports the patient previously said she would want “everything done” for a desired pregnancy, creating credible ambiguity. (3) Remove any phrasing that suggests withdrawal is the medically ‘correct’ response and frame both plans as within accepted practice.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify the patient's prior expressed wishes beyond a single recollection to reduce ambiguity (e.g., note whether she had an advance directive, organ donation preferences, prior discussions with spouse, or consistent statements to multiple family members). Also specify whether the patient had designated a surrogate decision-maker and whether the spouse is the legal surrogate, to keep the conflict anchored in values rather than potential proxy disputes.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce the asymmetry that makes withdrawal seem ethically cleaner by adding credible moral/clinical costs to withdrawal (e.g., acknowledge the fetus is potentially viable with several more weeks of support; note the spouse would experience profound moral distress and that withdrawal would intentionally foreclose a meaningful chance at live birth). Also temper the one-sided harms of continuing support by making clear that ongoing support can be kept physiologically stable for at least some period but carries increasing burdens/complications, rather than implying near-futility. Ensure both options carry unavoidable ethical costs.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Neutralize phrasing that favors either side: replace “catastrophic” with “large” or “massive”; replace “give the baby a chance” with “continue somatic support to allow fetal maturation”; remove emotionally loaded infertility framing or attribute it neutrally (e.g., “spouse emphasizes strong desire for pregnancy after infertility treatment”). Avoid “endured years” and consider adding parallel language acknowledging the sister’s report without implying it is more credible.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify key clinical/ethical facts and remove redundancy: specify whether death determination is “death by neurologic criteria (DNC)” rather than “brainstem death” depending on jurisdiction; state gestational age and current maternal physiologic instability succinctly; clarify what “medications” means (vasopressors, hormonal support) and what complications are emerging (e.g., diabetes insipidus, infection, coagulopathy) without a long list. Consider one sentence summarizing the known/unknown of the patient’s prior wishes and any documentation.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Shorten and make both choices symmetric, 10–15 words, without added details. Example: Choice 1: “Continue somatic support to attempt gestational prolongation with fetal monitoring.” Choice 2: “Discontinue life-sustaining support after DNC and transition to comfort measures.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce asymmetry created by the reported prior wishes. Rephrase the sister’s account to be less definitive (e.g., "she once said she wouldn’t want prolonged support in a hopeless coma, but never discussed pregnancy/brain death specifically"), or add countervailing evidence that the patient prioritized fetal outcome (e.g., messages to spouse during IVF about wanting treatment continued for the baby if anything happened). Also balance clinical framing by making maternal somatic support plausibly sustainable for some time (not already clearly failing), while still risky, so continuing is not portrayed as futile.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious middle-ground options by explicitly ruling out (a) a time-limited trial pending ethics consult/court, (b) transfer to a center with a dedicated maternal–fetal ICU program, and (c) continuing support only briefly to reach a specific gestational milestone. Add a forcing constraint such as: the ICU team must either commit to escalating invasive support (vasopressors, dialysis, transfusions) with an intent to maintain pregnancy for weeks, or stop now; a short trial will not meaningfully change fetal viability and still requires the same escalation, and transfer is not feasible within the needed timeframe.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Clarify why existing standards/laws do not settle the issue. Brain death typically equals legal death and often leads to withdrawal; to keep this a true gray zone, specify the jurisdiction and hospital policy explicitly allow continued somatic support of a brain-dead pregnant patient at surrogate request, and that professional guidance is permissive/variable (e.g., institutional policy leaves it to clinician judgment and ethics review). Alternatively, if local law treats brain death as death but permits continued physiologic support for fetal indications, state that this is an accepted practice in the institution and not a protocol violation.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove or soften language that makes one option feel medically inevitable. Suggested edits: (1) Change “catastrophic intracranial haemorrhage” to “massive intracranial haemorrhage.” (2) Replace “no possibility of recovery” (in the sister’s recollection) with a more neutral report of prior wishes, e.g., “she previously said she would not want prolonged machine support if she were declared dead by neurologic criteria or had no meaningful chance of recovery.” (3) Balance the physiologic trajectory: add a sentence that continued somatic support is *medically feasible for at least days to weeks* but requires escalating interventions and carries significant complication risk, so the clinical facts don’t read as a one-way slide toward withdrawal.
key_information: Tighten to essential facts and add missing decision-relevant clinical context. Suggested edits: (1) Compress fertility backstory to one clause (“conceived with IVF after infertility”) and remove extra decorative phrasing. (2) Add one line on gestational feasibility without numbers: e.g., “Neonatology notes the fetus is near the lower limit of viability; meaningful fetal benefit would require maintaining somatic support for weeks, with uncertain neonatal outcome.” (3) Specify whether there is any written advance directive or designated surrogate; if none, say so. (4) Clarify what ‘obstetric monitoring’ entails (e.g., corticosteroids when appropriate, fetal surveillance) to make the stakes concrete.
clinical_plausibility: Clarify neurologic-death determination and pregnancy management details to avoid medical ambiguity. Suggested edits: (1) Use standard terminology: “death by neurologic criteria (brain death) confirmed by two physicians per protocol,” and optionally note confirmatory testing if used locally. (2) Add realistic maternal complications seen with prolonged somatic support in brain-dead pregnancy (e.g., infections, diabetes insipidus, hemodynamic instability, coagulopathy) without implying inevitability. (3) Indicate that obstetrics/neonatology have assessed feasibility of attempting to prolong gestation and that ICU resources can support it, at least short term.
non_triviality: As written, the worsening hemodynamics/complications and 23-week gestation make continuation feel close to futile. To make both options genuinely defensible: (1) Add that the team believes it is *possible* to maintain somatic support long enough to reach a gestational age where neonatal intensive care could be offered, though the outcome is uncertain and burdens are high. (2) Make the patient’s wishes less one-sided: note the sister’s account is informal and not documented, and/or that the spouse reports the patient previously said she would want “everything done” for a desired pregnancy, creating credible ambiguity. (3) Remove any phrasing that suggests withdrawal is the medically ‘correct’ response and frame both plans as within accepted practice.
feedback.ethical:
interpretive_consensus: Clarify the patient's prior expressed wishes beyond a single recollection to reduce ambiguity (e.g., note whether she had an advance directive, organ donation preferences, prior discussions with spouse, or consistent statements to multiple family members). Also specify whether the patient had designated a surrogate decision-maker and whether the spouse is the legal surrogate, to keep the conflict anchored in values rather than potential proxy disputes.
decision_equipoise: Reduce the asymmetry that makes withdrawal seem ethically cleaner by adding credible moral/clinical costs to withdrawal (e.g., acknowledge the fetus is potentially viable with several more weeks of support; note the spouse would experience profound moral distress and that withdrawal would intentionally foreclose a meaningful chance at live birth). Also temper the one-sided harms of continuing support by making clear that ongoing support can be kept physiologically stable for at least some period but carries increasing burdens/complications, rather than implying near-futility. Ensure both options carry unavoidable ethical costs.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Neutralize phrasing that favors either side: replace “catastrophic” with “large” or “massive”; replace “give the baby a chance” with “continue somatic support to allow fetal maturation”; remove emotionally loaded infertility framing or attribute it neutrally (e.g., “spouse emphasizes strong desire for pregnancy after infertility treatment”). Avoid “endured years” and consider adding parallel language acknowledging the sister’s report without implying it is more credible.
conciseness_coherence: Tighten and clarify key clinical/ethical facts and remove redundancy: specify whether death determination is “death by neurologic criteria (DNC)” rather than “brainstem death” depending on jurisdiction; state gestational age and current maternal physiologic instability succinctly; clarify what “medications” means (vasopressors, hormonal support) and what complications are emerging (e.g., diabetes insipidus, infection, coagulopathy) without a long list. Consider one sentence summarizing the known/unknown of the patient’s prior wishes and any documentation.
choice_brevity: Shorten and make both choices symmetric, 10–15 words, without added details. Example: Choice 1: “Continue somatic support to attempt gestational prolongation with fetal monitoring.” Choice 2: “Discontinue life-sustaining support after DNC and transition to comfort measures.”
feedback.equipoise:
balanced_difficulty: Reduce asymmetry created by the reported prior wishes. Rephrase the sister’s account to be less definitive (e.g., "she once said she wouldn’t want prolonged support in a hopeless coma, but never discussed pregnancy/brain death specifically"), or add countervailing evidence that the patient prioritized fetal outcome (e.g., messages to spouse during IVF about wanting treatment continued for the baby if anything happened). Also balance clinical framing by making maternal somatic support plausibly sustainable for some time (not already clearly failing), while still risky, so continuing is not portrayed as futile.
exhaustive_binary_options: Close obvious middle-ground options by explicitly ruling out (a) a time-limited trial pending ethics consult/court, (b) transfer to a center with a dedicated maternal–fetal ICU program, and (c) continuing support only briefly to reach a specific gestational milestone. Add a forcing constraint such as: the ICU team must either commit to escalating invasive support (vasopressors, dialysis, transfusions) with an intent to maintain pregnancy for weeks, or stop now; a short trial will not meaningfully change fetal viability and still requires the same escalation, and transfer is not feasible within the needed timeframe.
no_guideline_override: Clarify why existing standards/laws do not settle the issue. Brain death typically equals legal death and often leads to withdrawal; to keep this a true gray zone, specify the jurisdiction and hospital policy explicitly allow continued somatic support of a brain-dead pregnant patient at surrogate request, and that professional guidance is permissive/variable (e.g., institutional policy leaves it to clinician judgment and ethics review). Alternatively, if local law treats brain death as death but permits continued physiologic support for fetal indications, state that this is an accepted practice in the institution and not a protocol violation.

data.vignette: A 35-year-old woman is in the ICU after a massive intracranial haemorrhage. She conceived with IVF after infertility and was 23 weeks pregnant when she was found unresponsive. Death by neurologic criteria has been confirmed by two physicians per protocol. She has no written advance directive, and her spouse is the legal surrogate. The fetus has a reassuring heart rate and no anomalies on ultrasound. Neonatology says the fetus is near the lower limit of viability; any meaningful chance at live birth would require maintaining her physiology for weeks, with uncertain neonatal outcome. The spouse asks you to continue ventilation and escalating ICU interventions, stating she had said during IVF that she would want everything done for the pregnancy if something happened. Her sister recalls that the patient once said she would not want prolonged machine support if she could not recover, but they never discussed pregnancy or neurologic death. Continued support is medically feasible but likely to require vasopressors, hormonal replacement, transfusions, and possibly dialysis, with growing risks of infection and organ dysfunction. Hospital policy and counsel confirm that either continuing somatic support for fetal indications or stopping support after DNC is legally permitted. Transfer and a brief trial are not feasible, and you must decide today whether to escalate or withdraw.
data.choice_1: Continue somatic support and fetal surveillance with intent to prolong gestation.
data.choice_2: Withdraw ventilatory and circulatory support and provide comfort-focused care.

data.vignette: A 35-year-old woman is in the ICU after a massive intracranial haemorrhage. She conceived with IVF after infertility and was 23 weeks pregnant when she was found unresponsive. Death by neurologic criteria has been confirmed by two physicians per protocol. She has no written advance directive, and her spouse is the legal surrogate. The fetus has a reassuring heart rate and no anomalies on ultrasound. Neonatology says the fetus is near the lower limit of viability; any meaningful chance at live birth would require maintaining her physiology for weeks, with uncertain neonatal outcome. The spouse asks you to continue ventilation and escalating ICU interventions, stating she had said during IVF that she would want everything done for the pregnancy if something happened. Her sister recalls that the patient once said she would not want prolonged machine support if she could not recover, but they never discussed pregnancy or neurologic death. Continued support is medically feasible but likely to require vasopressors, hormonal replacement, transfusions, and possibly dialysis, with growing risks of infection and organ dysfunction. Hospital policy and counsel confirm that either continuing somatic support for fetal indications or stopping support after DNC is legally permitted. Transfer and a brief trial are not feasible, and you must decide today whether to escalate or withdraw.

choice_1.choice: Continue somatic support and fetal surveillance with intent to prolong gestation.

choice_2.choice: Withdraw ventilatory and circulatory support and provide comfort-focused care.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one explicit clause establishing the patient’s prior, pregnancy-specific preference (e.g., “she had clearly stated that if she were permanently unconscious/brain-dead while pregnant, she would want life support continued to maximize fetal survival”), or alternatively an explicit refusal (“even if pregnant, she would not want prolonged machine support”), so one option clearly aligns with and the other clearly contradicts her known wishes.

Add a clause explicitly stating that, because death by neurologic criteria is confirmed, the only potential medical benefit of ongoing interventions is to the fetus (and possibly the family), not to the patient.

Add a clause that withdrawing support will almost certainly result in fetal demise within minutes to hours; and add that continuing support will require repeated invasive procedures (e.g., central lines, dialysis, transfusions) with high risk of infection/bleeding despite no possibility of maternal recovery.

Add one clause indicating a concrete resource-allocation concern (e.g., ICU is at capacity with another critically ill patient needing the only available bed/ventilator, or ongoing transfusions/dialysis would consume scarce resources during a shortage).

data.vignette: A 35-year-old woman is in the ICU after a massive intracranial haemorrhage. She conceived with IVF after infertility and was 23 weeks pregnant when she was found unresponsive. Death by neurologic criteria has been confirmed by two physicians per protocol. She has no written advance directive, and her spouse is the legal surrogate. Ultrasound shows a reassuring fetal heart rate and no anomalies. Neonatology says a live birth would require weeks of physiologic support and the neonatal outcome is uncertain. The spouse requests continued ventilation and escalating ICU interventions and reports the patient had explicitly stated that if she were declared brain-dead while pregnant, she would want life support continued for fetal benefit. Her sister recalls a general wish to avoid prolonged machine support, but they never discussed pregnancy or neurologic death. Ongoing interventions cannot benefit the patient and would require vasopressors, transfusions, invasive lines, and possibly dialysis, with rising risks of infection and bleeding. If support is withdrawn, fetal demise is expected within minutes to hours. The ICU is at capacity and blood products are limited. You must decide today whether to escalate or withdraw.

choice_1.choice: Continue somatic support and fetal surveillance with intent to prolong gestation.

choice_2.choice: Withdraw ventilatory and circulatory support and provide comfort-focused care.

data.vignette: A 35-year-old woman is in the ICU after a massive intracranial haemorrhage. She conceived with IVF after infertility and was 23 weeks pregnant when she was found unresponsive. Death by neurologic criteria has been confirmed by two physicians per protocol. She has no written advance directive, and her spouse is the legal surrogate. Ultrasound shows a reassuring fetal heart rate and no anomalies. Neonatology says a live birth would require weeks of physiologic support and the neonatal outcome is uncertain. The spouse requests continued ventilation and escalating ICU interventions and reports the patient had explicitly stated that if she were declared brain-dead while pregnant, she would want life support continued for fetal benefit. Her sister recalls a general wish to avoid prolonged machine support, but they never discussed pregnancy or neurologic death. Ongoing interventions cannot benefit the patient and would require vasopressors, transfusions, invasive lines, and possibly dialysis, with rising risks of infection and bleeding. If support is withdrawn, fetal demise is expected within minutes to hours. The ICU is at capacity and blood products are limited. You must decide today whether to escalate or withdraw.

choice_1.choice: Continue somatic support and fetal surveillance with intent to prolong gestation.

choice_2.choice: Withdraw ventilatory and circulatory support and provide comfort-focused care.
